intro: Acer mono subsp. okamotoanum, commonly known as the Okamoto maple, is a deciduous tree native to Japan. It is characterized by its distinctive palmate leaves that turn vibrant red in the autumn. The tree typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters and has a narrow, upright growth habit. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, appearing in clusters before the leaves emerge in spring. The bark is smooth and grayish-brown, becoming fissured with age.
